Change has been successfully merged
This change needs some tests

I added some test cases in tests/oem/meta/fileio.cpp.
Please help to check, thank you.
Similar to the write counterpart, I prefer we name this `decode_oem_meta_file_io_read_req()`
Done
Please remove the `wip: ` prefix if this is no-longer a work-in-progress change.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Please say something more descriptive here. Can you provide some context for the message and maybe document the serialised message layout (that way we can make sure it matches the implementation).
Done. Please check, thank you.
Done
Hi Lora, I've outlined a number of concerns inline.
Please name this `pldm_oem_meta_fileio_read_option`

Done. Change to pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_option.
Please check, thank you.
Similar to the review comment above: `pldm_oem_meta_fileio_read_req`, and fix the doxygen to be consistent.

Done. Change to pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_req.
Please check, thank you.

This is not a valid flexible array definition. Please see the guidance here:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md?plain=1#L89-L102

Done. Use pointers instead of flexible arrays.
Please check, thank you.
`pldm_oem_meta_fileio_read_data_info`, and fix the doxygen.

Done. Change to pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_data_info.
Please check, thank you.
`file_io` or `fileio`? Can we please be consistent.

Done. All modified parts are changed to file_io.
Please check, thank you.
If `struct pldm_oem_meta_read_file_req` contains a flexible array member then you must also pass the length of the `req` object through the API.

Done. Added req_length parameter to check whether the total length of the requested message meets expectations.
Please check, thank you.

You use `req->length` in the call immediately below, but you've neither checked the return value of `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` here, nor verified that the decoded length is in any way sensible. `msgbuf` will prevent out-of-bounds reads, but let's avoid even attempting them if we can determine the value isn't sensible to begin with. For instance `req->length < payload_length` seems like a sensible check.

Done. Checks whether the total length of the request message is the same as the provided length plus the minimum decoded length.
Please check, thank you.
Modify according to suggestions. Please help to review. Thank you.
A bit of a nit-pick, but I would prefer we drop the bullet points, they don't contribute much to the communication.
I've removed the bullet points description. Please check, thank you.
Hi Lora, I have a few comments inline.
This also needs some tests added.
`FILEIO` here is inconsistent with using an underscore between `file` and `io` in the type names. Please use `FILE_IO` here, or no underscore everywhere else.
Change to FILE_IO. Please check, thank you.
Also here.
Change to FILE_IO. Please check, thank you.
If we have a pair of parameters that represent an object and its length, please be consistent and put the length parameter after the object pointer. In this case, order `req_length` after `req`.
Done. Please check, thank you.
I don't understand why a read request would be providing data. Wouldn't this be the case for the response?

read_info needs to include the information of the reading file.
Take reading file data as an example: read_info needs to contain length (read file length), transferFlag, highOffset and lowOffset to know the starting position, length and transfer progress of the read file.
I'm sorry, but your explanation is not making sense to me. Why are we dealing with an opaque array?

If we want to extract the information of the read file io command, we need dealing with the array here.
Please tell me how I can resolve your concerns, thank you.

That would make sense if you were decoding the read _response_, but this function is decoding the read _request_. There can't be data, the message is requesting that a read be performed.

Please add a document in `docs/oem/meta/` that describes the serialised layout of each of the messages (requests and responses) that you're adding in this series. This should be in the same manner as done in the DMTF documents: A table containing type and description columns, with rows documenting the order of the fields in the message. This needs to be written down and considered in its own right, so that we have a reference for the _implementation_ of the serialisation functions (encode/decode).

Thank you for your reply.
I will add a file_io_function_description.md under the docs/oem/meta/ path to explain the use of the read file io command, thank you.

I have added file_io_function_description.md to explain the use of the read file io command.
Please help to review, thank you.
Done
Hi Lora, along with resolving the discussions in-line, this change still needs test cases added.
I have revised it. Please help to review. Thank you.
Perhaps `-EOVERFLOW`?
Done. Please check, thank you.
See the discussion on PS 12.
Done
Modifications have been made according to the suggestions. Please review. Thank you.

This isn't readable and doesn't render as a table:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/libpldm/+/refs/changes/58/72758/19/docs/oem/meta/file_io_function_description.md

Please fix the markdown:

https://github.github.com/gfm/#tables-extension-
It has been modified according to the suggestions, but the table displayed by markdown does not seem to be as expected ?
Done
I think these enum members should be assigned explicit values.
Done. Please check. Thank you.
This should be a flexible array like we have on line 36 above (along with the helper function for accessing the data in C++).
Done. Please check. Thank you.
Please see how the checks are done in `decode_oem_meta_file_io_write_req()` above and do the same here.
Done. Please check. Thank you.
Hi Lora, I've provided an explicit example of the markdown table syntax example I was after. The documentation isn't readable as it stands and this needs to be fixed.

You've replaced it with HTML content - that's not what the documentation I linked to on PS19 was suggesting at all. The HTML in the GFM documentation is demonstrating the _rendered output_ from the markdown syntax. 

The example syntax is:

```
| foo | bar |
| --- | --- |
| baz | bim |
```

Which renders like:

| foo | bar |
| --- | --- |
| baz | bim |

That's all I'm asking for here.

Thank you for your explanation.
I have modified it as suggested. Please check, thank you.

According to the link check, it seems that the table can be displayed normally.
link：https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/libpldm/+/refs/changes/58/72758/22/docs/oem/meta/file_io_function_description.md
Done
Hi Lora, thanks for the documentation, it's been quite helpful. I have some follow-up thoughts now that I better understand what you're trying to achieve.

This file is documenting your OEM message types, not any specific functions. The implementation in libpldm then provides APIs to encode and decode these messages, but that's a separate matter. This document should only refer to _messages_.
Done. Please check, thank you.
messages
Done. Please check, thank you.
This should be the name of the message type.

Modify to the name of the message type.
Please check, thank you.
Done
Message format
Done. Please check, thank you.
You're implementing an OEM PLDM message, these must be PLDM completion codes, not errno values. errno values are for the _APIs of the library_, PLDM completion codes are for _PLDM messages_.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Message type
Please make this a header and not a bullet-point. Same for the rest of the table titles.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Message type
Done. Please check, thank you.
Message type.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Message type.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Message type.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Can we just call this `option`? The `read` prefix seems redundant to me.
Done. Please check, thank you.

Thank you for your suggestion, it has been modified according to the suggestion.
Please check, thank you.
This can go away with the suggestion above.
Done. Please check, thank you.

Okay, so thanks to your message format documentation I understand what you're trying to do here. But I think we can do better. Why not properly decode the structure based on the value of `req->read_option`? This way we can drop the flexible array member from `struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_req` and replace it with a union over (at least) `struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_data_info`. I'll add a comment on the header.

Thank you for your suggestion, it has been modified according to the suggestion.
Please check, thank you.
Done
Hi Lora, thanks for the changes. I'm picking at the details a bit here because I want future changes adding support for OEM messages to use this work as a reference. Thanks for bearing with me.
Ah, I just realised the file uses 'function_description' in the name. Can we please rename it to `file-io.md`? Again, we're documenting the message formats here, not any libpldm APIs.
I have been renamed to file-io.md. Thank you.

The documentation for messages shouldn't mention APIs. APIs involve a whole set of further choices. Here we're just trying to nail down the message format, so the location, type and semantics of data in a serialised message.

This should be e.g. `Read`. Generally messages imply both request and response, so we don't list that here.
I removed unnecessary titles "List of read file IO messages".
Sorry, I should have clarified in my previous comment: This should be `Read Message Format`.
Done. Please check, thank you.

This should be `Table 1`, right? The numbering for the tables below should be incremented.

So we should have:

```
### Table 1. Read Request

...
```
Done. Please check, thank you.

I just had a thought: Perhaps it would be best if we split these into separate `Name` and `Description` columns. Put the bit on the left of the `
` into the `Name` column, and the bit on the right into the `Description` column. Also, I think it might be best if we rename the `Byte` column to `Offset`. So the table becomes: ``` | Offset | Type | Name | Description | | ------ | ---- | ---- | ----------- | ``` Please use this scheme for the tables below where appropriate (i.e. what is currently `Table 1` uses a different scheme and my suggestion above doesn't apply there).
Done. Please check, thank you.

This is `Table 2`, so:

```
### Table 2. Read response

...
```
Done. Please check, thank you.
Table number needs updating based on the above.
Done. Please check, thank you.

Please test each of your changes with `./scripts/pre-submit` and make sure there are no errors. These tests need guards around them so that they aren't built when the testing symbols are excluded from the ABI.

The straight-forward way to do this is with `git rebase -x ./scripts/pre-submit origin/main`.

Sorry, I encountered the following problems during execution. It seems that the mctp.h file under the linux repo cannot be found and stopped.
I tried to clone the linux repo at the same level as the libpldm folder, but this error message still appeared.

Execution result：
[1/86] Compiling C object src/libpldm.so.0.8.0.p/transport_af-mctp.c.o

Hi Andrew, 
I have some questions to ask before making the changes.
Please see the link: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/72758/comment/fd443ca9_2bd76486/

Okay, a bit late to the party here, but can this please be combined to a `uint16_t` with PLDM-endianness? Manually reconstructing an offset seems way more error-prone than `pldm_msgbuf_extract(buf, req->offset)` where `req->offset` is `uint16_t`.
I will change it to a parameter offset, type is uint16_t.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Seems odd to me that the size is `uint16` but the `length` field in the messages is `uint8`. This means we need ~64 transactions to read a full-sized file. Is there a reason for this?
I will change the length type in struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_req to uint16_t so that users can obtain more data at one time.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Combine this into a `uint16_t` here also.
I will change it to a parameter offset, type is uint16_t.
Done. Please check, thank you.
See comments on message documentation.
I will change it to a parameter offset, type is uint16_t.
Done. Please check, thank you.

See my comment about extensible structs here:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/72759/comment/0434ff06_ed1bd477/

This one also needs the `size_t version` field.

If the size_t version field is added to struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_req as suggested, the following changes will occur：
1. PLDM_OEM_META_FILE_IO_READ_REQ_MIN_LENGTH will be changed to 11u.
2. We need to add size_t to the pldm_msgbuf_extract function to extract the version.
3. After extracting the version, check whether the size of version and struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_req are the same.

The second one has more changes. I want to confirm whether this change is correct first. If it is correct, I will use the pldm_msgbuf_extract function to extract the size_t type.

> PLDM_OEM_META_FILE_IO_READ_REQ_MIN_LENGTH will be changed to 11u.

No, because we're not going to encode `version` in the message itself. The structure of the struct is not the same as the message - the idea behind the encode/decode functions is we make the messages easier to work with in C. The representations do not need to be equivalent (and shouldn't be). The `version` field is purely a C construct dealing with the shape of the `struct` definition for API forwards-compatibility.

> We need to add size_t to the pldm_msgbuf_extract function to extract the version.

No need, see the above. The version field just allows us to accommodate any new values for `option` added in the future but retain backwards compatibility of the library API.

> After extracting the version, check whether the size of version and struct pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_req are the same.

Not necessary, as above.

Thank you for your explanation.

This should be `-EPROTO`. It's not an invalid parameter, it's invalid data from the sender (a protocol violation with respect to the libpldm's understanding of the message defintion).
Done. Please help to review, thank you.
